Description: Sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery kotyle preserving full profile; interior: glazed (fired brown); exterior, from top: black-figure frieze with animal procession to right, bird (head and tail feathers missing, with added red on wing and breast), and four-legged animal, possibly a bull (hind leg and one front hoof remaining); incised splinter rosettes and blobs as filling ornament; below, four narrow and one broad black band; rays; on underside, broad and narrow concentric bands around central dot.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For parallels, see Stillwell and Benson, ‘Corinth: Results of Excavations Conducted by the American School of Classical Studies at Athens - Vol. XV, Part 3: The Potters Quarter - The Pottery’, Princeton (1984), pl. 27, fig. 574-576. A.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 121, pl. XXXVII, no. 342)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 229, no. 149)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.235) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5733 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
